title: China's 'Black Monday' will not derail rate rises, says Mark Carney
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sat, Aug 29, 2015, 19:26 BST - UK Markets closed China's 'Black Monday' will not derail rate rises, says Mark Carney By Rebecca Burn-Callander | Telegraph – 19 minutes ago 123.75 -0.04 
The Bank of England governor claims that the UK's 'ongoing domestic strength' is a match for turbulent headwinds from the East 
China’s financial woes will not derail plans to raise interest rates, the Bank of England Governor has said, arguing that the UK economy is still fighting fit. 
Speaking at the Economic Policy Symposium hosted by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, today, Mark Carney acknowledged that the dramatic decline in Chinese stocks had sparked volatility in Western markets but claimed that it would not knock his economic plans off course. 
“The direct exposure of the UK economy to China is relatively modest,” he told delegates. “Developments in China are unlikely to change the process of rate increases.” 
Some £74bn was wiped off the value of the UK’s FTSE 100 companies in the two days following the Black Monday crash and some financial pundits warned that the impact on growth could force central banks to keep interest rates on hold . 
However, the FTSE 100 rebounded strongly in the second half of the week . Mr Carney noted the “ongoing domestic strength” of the UK market in his address, adding that the decision as to when to start the process of raising rates would still take place “around the turn of this year”. 
"In the UK, consumer confidence is at its highest level in over a decade and retail sales have been growing at well above past average rates," he said. "Firms’ investment intensions are robust. And inflation expectations remain consistent with our 2pc target." 
Mr Carney gave strong indications that interest rates would rise by early 2016 in July of this year. Higher interest rates will provide long-awaited relief to savers, who have seen their returns shrink in the wake of the financial crisis but will increase the pressure on borrowers, who will have to pay more for their mortgages and credit card bills. The increase in interest rates could also hit the housing market. 
Earlier this month, Mr Carney hinted that global headwinds would not stand in the way of rate rises , saying: “Next (Other OTC: NXGPF - news ) time we're in front of you there will be lots of uncertainty, some of which we won't have predicted, but that's not a justification for permanent stasis.”
